issue_description:
# In E2E tests, re-do build and dependency installation when build files not available

We currently delete the `build_files` artifact in GitHub Actions after 1 day. This artifact contains the build that the E2E tests need to run, which means that contributors currently only have 1 day to get their E2E tests passing (i.e. by rerunning them) before they have to rerun all the tests.

If the build artifact is not available, we should automatically re-generate it by installing dependencies and performing the production build. Note that to solve this issue, you will need to figure out a way to tell whether a build artifact is available.

This issue was raised here:

* https://github.com/oppia/oppia/pull/17506#issuecomment-1447855041

issue_comments.body: @U8NWXD can I work on this one?

Before I can assign this to you, please describe the changes you plan to implement. This can be a high-level description--we just want to make sure you have a viable plan.

This process is discussed in more detail on the wiki: https://github.com/oppia/oppia/wiki/Contributing-code-to-Oppia#choosing-a-good-first-issue

Hi,  may I please grab it?  There could be 2 strategies for checking whether the artifact is there: 
1. implement alert upon artifact deletion.
2. Work through GitHub API to list content of the artifact's parent.
Sure, I'm not going to work on it.

@potap75 could you expand on your two strategies? How can we trigger alerts upon artifact deletion? Does GitHub have an API for that? What GitHub API would use use to check whether the artifact is present?
@U8NWXD Maybe we can use custom retention period that is " retention-days: "  for artifact and increase it so that we have more days to run E2E tests.
can you please assign me that issue ?

@tehami02 we have a retention period of 1 day because we have limited artifact storage space on GitHub, and the build artifacts are rather large (you can see an example that's over 1 GB here: https://github.com/oppia/oppia/actions/runs/4331127633). I don't think we can increase that period without running out of space.

@Khadim-swe if you want to work on this issue, please follow our [instructions for taking up a good first issue](https://github.com/oppia/oppia/wiki/Contributing-code-to-Oppia#choosing-a-good-first-issue). Specifically, make sure your comment "describes in more detail how you'd tackle the issue (e.g. explain which file(s) you would modify and what changes you would make). If your explanation makes sense, we'll assign the issue to you."
@U8NWXD I think we can use github api to get the artifact ID and check if the artifact ID is empty or not. In this way we will know if the artifact is available or not.

hey @U8NWXD could you please allow me to start work on this issue ?
Please share some related resources so that I could come up with the best optimized solution.
@anshikavashistha I assigned @tehami02 since they proposed a solution first, but you're welcome to take up one of our other good first issues

Okay sure I will definitely look forward to it.

#17700 Fixed in pull request : In E2E tests, re-do build and dependency installation when build files not available #17531

Hi @U8NWXD, I'd like to try out this issue. I'm thinking a possible good approach would be to check if the file exists using a modified version of @tehami02's code. However, I would instead run a step directly before the "downloads build files artifact" to check if the artifact is there. If the artifact is not there, I would run a step that would re-run build/re-create the artifact, looking something like this:
```
# code above here is step that currently runs directly before downloading build file
      - name: Check if build artifact exists # <- code from tehami02
        id: check_build_artifact
        uses: actions/github-script@v3
        with:
          script: |
            const artifacts = await github.actions.listWorkflowRunArtifacts({
              owner: context.repo.owner,
              repo: context.repo.repo,
              run_id: ${{ github.run_id }},
            });
            const buildFilesArtifact = artifacts.data.find(a => a.name === 'build_files');
            console.log('Build Artifact' + (buildFilesArtifact ? 'exists.' : 'does not exist.'));
            core.setOutput('build_artifact_exists', buildFilesArtifact)
        }
      token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

      - name: Generate build artifact
        if: steps.check_build_artifact.outputs.build_artifact_exists == false
        uses: # <- run steps in build in e2e_tetts
        

      - name: Download build files artifact # <- line 137 in e2e_tests.yml
        ...
```
Depending on how I might run the steps in build, I was thinking of possibly creating an action that performs all the steps in build, calling that action in both the `build` and `e2e_test` jobs.
@CaryXiao1 assigned!

Created #17812 to try and fix issue #17700. Since my code is run via Github, I'm currently just using the PR to make sure that the e2e tests still run and to later ensure that I can later re-compute the build artifact if it has been deleted.
@CaryXiao1 please update the project board with the expected merge date! thanks..
Hi @Shivkant-Chauhan! I'm not sure exactly how to do this/if I have the permissions, as I haven't been onboarded to a team yet. My goal is to finish this by Saturday.
thanks @CaryXiao1. I will update this!

Previous PR was closed because I accidentally force-pushed in one of the commits. I will open another PR soon; before the 1st PR was closed, I got almost all the E2E tests to pass so I believe all I really need to do left is test the re-construction of the artifact.

> Previous PR was closed because I accidentally force-pushed in one of the commits. I will open another PR soon; before the 1st PR was closed, I got almost all the E2E tests to pass so I believe all I really need to do left is test the re-construction of the artifact.

just a follow-up for this, can you update on when will you expect to open another PR for the issue. so that I can update this on the project board. thanks..

Yep @Shivkant-Chauhan - I forgot to mention that I opened #17891. As for updating when it will be merged, it should be at latest this Friday, since I still need to re-run tests and make sure that it works correctly when the artifact does not exist by re-running the e2e_test specifically.
thanks for updating @CaryXiao1

We currently delete the `build_files` artifact in GitHub Actions after 1 day. This artifact contains the build that the E2E tests need to run, which means that contributors currently only have 1 day to get their E2E tests passing (i.e. by rerunning them) before they have to rerun all the tests.

If the build artifact is not available, we should automatically re-generate it by installing dependencies and performing the production build. Note that to solve this issue, you will need to figure out a way to tell whether a build artifact is available.

This issue was raised here:

* https://github.com/oppia/oppia/pull/17506#issuecomment-1447855041

@tehami02 we have a retention period of 1 day because we have limited artifact storage space on GitHub, and the build artifacts are rather large (you can see an example that's over 1 GB here: https://github.com/oppia/oppia/actions/runs/4331127633). @U8NWXD I think we can use github api to get the artifact ID and check if the artifact ID is empty or not. In this way we will know if the artifact is available or not.


@U8NWXD I have researched more and came up with this method : 
This workflow runs on a schedule every day at midnight. It first checks if the build_files artifact exists and is less than 24 hours old. If it does, the workflow exits without doing anything else. If it doesn't, the workflow installs dependencies and generates the build artifact. Finally, the workflow uploads the generated build artifact as a workflow run artifact.


yaml code below.

name: Regenerate Build Artifact

on:
  schedule:
    - cron: '0 0 * * *' # run every day at midnight

jobs:
  regenerate-build-artifact:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Check if build artifact exists
        id: check_build_artifact
        uses: actions/github-script@v3
        with:
          script: |
            const artifacts = await github.actions.listWorkflowRunArtifacts({
              owner: context.repo.owner,
              repo: context.repo.repo,
              run_id: ${{ github.run_id }},
            });
            const buildFilesArtifact = artifacts.data.find(a => a.name === 'build_files');
            if (buildFilesArtifact && buildFilesArtifact.created_at > new Date(Date.now() - 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000).toISOString()) {
              console.log('Build artifact exists and is less than 24 hours old');
              core.setOutput('build_artifact_exists', 'true');
            } else {
              console.log('Build artifact does not exist or is older than 24 hours');
              core.setOutput('build_artifact_exists', 'false');
            }
          token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

      - name: Generate build artifact
        if: steps.check_build_artifact.outputs.build_artifact_exists == 'false'
        run: |
          npm install # or whatever command installs your dependencies
          npm run build # or whatever command generates your build artifact
        # upload the generated build artifact as a workflow run artifact
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v2
        with:
          name: build_files
          path: path/to/build_files


I think this method can solve our issue.

hey @U8NWXD could you please allow me to start work on this issue ?
Please share some related resources so that I could come up with the best optimized solution.

@tehami02 I think your solution would work, but I think we do it a little more efficiently. In the `e2e_test` job, we currently download the build artifact, which fails if it's missing:

https://github.com/oppia/oppia/blob/3628528c259cbf9ada8b850db5d1eb0e4536c8d5/.github/workflows/e2e_tests.yml#L137

Instead, we can check whether the artifact exists (using the code you suggested in https://github.com/oppia/oppia/issues/17531#issuecomment-1455121191). If the artifact exists, we download and unzip it. If it doesn't exist, we run the build and installation steps again. (I don't think it makes sense to re-upload the artifact since reruns should be uncommon). Does that make sense?

@anshikavashistha I assigned @tehami02 since they proposed a solution first, but you're welcome to take up one of our other good first issues

Okay sure I will definitely look forward to it.

golden_answers: @Khadim-swe if you want to work on this issue, please follow our [instructions for taking up a good first issue](https://github.com/oppia/oppia/wiki/Contributing-code-to-Oppia#choosing-a-good-first-issue). questions_generated: What is the purpose of the `build_files` artifact in the oppia_oppia repository's E2E tests?
Why is the `build_files` artifact deleted after 1 day in GitHub Actions?
What challenge does the deletion of the `build_files` artifact pose for contributors?
How can one determine if the `build_files` artifact is available in the GitHub Actions workflow?
What strategies were suggested for handling the unavailability of the `build_files` artifact?
Why is it not feasible to increase the retention period of the `build_files` artifact beyond 1 day?
What is the proposed method to automate the re-generation of the `build_files` artifact if it is unavailable?
What are the potential technical challenges in implementing a solution to check the availability of the `build_files` artifact?
golden_answers_generated: The `build_files` artifact contains the production build that the E2E tests require to run. It is crucial for ensuring that the tests operate under the same conditions as they would in a production environment.
The `build_files` artifact is deleted after 1 day due to limited artifact storage space on GitHub. The build artifacts can be quite large, over 1 GB, which necessitates managing storage constraints.

Contributors have only 1 day to rerun their E2E tests to get them passing before the `build_files` artifact is deleted. If the artifact is deleted, they have to regenerate it by reinstalling dependencies and performing the production build.
One can use the GitHub API to check if the artifact ID is present or empty, indicating whether the `build_files` artifact is available or not.
Two strategies were suggested: implementing an alert upon artifact deletion and using the GitHub API to list the content of the artifact's parent directory to check for availability.
Increasing the retention period is not feasible due to the large size of the build artifacts, which could lead to running out of GitHub's limited artifact storage space.

The proposed method involves running a scheduled workflow every day at midnight. This workflow checks if the `build_files` artifact exists and is recent. If not, it installs dependencies and performs a production build to regenerate the artifact.

Technical challenges include determining the most efficient way to check artifact availability using the GitHub API, managing API rate limits, and ensuring that the solution integrates seamlessly with the existing E2E testing framework.
